qas.question: What font technology has reduced the need for transliteration?
What kind of restrictions are there on Russian speaking typists?
What coding was created in Russia?
What alphabet is used to transliterate English?
What language was the QWERTY keyboard first programmed to be used in?

plausible_answers.text: the extension of Unicode character encoding

qas.question: What extension fully incorporates the Latin alphabet?

context: Because of many <b5_0>technical<b5_0/> restrictions in computing and also because of the unavailability of Cyrillic keyboards abroad, Russian is often transliterated using the <b7_0><b8_0>Latin<b8_0/><b7_0/> alphabet. For example, <a0_0>мороз<a0_0/> ('<a3_0>frost<a3_0/>') is transliterated moroz, and <a1_0>мышь<a1_0/> ('<a4_0>mouse<a4_0/>'), mysh or myš'. Once commonly used by the majority of those living outside Russia, transliteration is being used less frequently by Russian-speaking typists in favor of <b9_0>the extension of <a2_0><b6_0>Unicode character encoding<b9_0/><b6_0/>,<a2_0/> which fully incorporates the Russian alphabet. Free programs leveraging this Unicode extension are available which allow users to type Russian characters, even on Western 'QWERTY' keyboards.
